title-group.article-title: Ubiquitin degradation of the Ribonuclease H2 subunit B Rnh2B regulates the virulence of Cryptococcus neoformans

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: The ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) regulates protein degradation in eukaryotes by polyubiquitinating substrate proteins, with F-box proteins serving as key components for substrate recognition. Research has shown that the absence of Cdc4, an F-box protein in C. neoformans, decreases virulence, yet the mechanisms by which Cdc4 affects these processes remain unclear. Using an iTRAQ-based proteomic strategy, we recognized Ribonuclease H2 subunit B (Rnh2B) as a target substrate for Cdc4. Protein-protein interaction assays have confirmed the interaction between Cdc4 and Rnh2B, indicating that Cdc4 regulates Rnh2B stability through ubiquitination. Functional analyses revealed that both the knockout and overexpression of RNH2B impair growth at 37°C, with the latter also affecting cellular membrane integrity and growth under osmotic stress conditions. Pathogenicity assays revealed that the deletion of RNH2B results in reduced virulence, whereas its overexpression leads to a complete loss of pathogenicity. Longitudinal tracking of fungal infection progression illustrated that mice lungs infected with rnh2BΔ mutants maintained a low yet stable fungal burden, in contrast to a significant reduction in fungal load observed in conjunction with RNH2B overexpression, ultimately leading to complete clearance. Analysis of host immune responses indicated a correlation between diminished virulence in the RNH2BOE strain and robust host immune activation. Notably, both the RNH2BOE strain and the cdc4Δ mutant induced analogous adaptive immune responses, facilitating the clearance of C. neoformans infection. Collectively, our findings propose a model wherein Cdc4 mediates the ubiquitination and degradation of Rnh2B, thereby exerting regulatory control over the pathogenicity of C. neoformans.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cryptococcus neoformans is a yeast pathogen with thick capsules recognized for its capability to induce life-threatening cryptococcal meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals [1]. Globally, it is estimated that there are about 194,100 new cases of cryptococcal infections each year, leading to approximately 147,100 deaths [2]. Following infection, C. neoformans has developed several adaptations allowing it to colonize and thrive within the host, which includes three classical virulence factors: (i) the capacity to grow at mammalian core temperatures, (ii) the production of a polysaccharide capsule, and (iii) the synthesis of melanin [3]. Current therapeutic modalities targeting C. neoformans predominantly encompass polyenes (e.g. amphotericin B), the pyrimidine analog (5-fluorocytosine), and azole antifungals (e.g. fluconazole) [4]. However, reliance on monotherapy with these antifungal agents has precipitated a considerable incidence of resistance development. Furthermore, the introduction of novel antifungal agents, specifically echinocandins, has demonstrated limited efficacy against emerging strains of C. neoformans [5]. Recent trends indicate an alarming increase in the prevalence of cryptococcal meningitis, attributed to rising numbers of HIV-infected individuals, organ transplant recipients, and patients undergoing immunotherapy, particularly those with CD4+ T cell counts below 100 cells/μl. This burgeoning prevalence burdens global health systems considerably [6,7]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to identify novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of cryptococcosis and to develop innovative therapeutic strategies.

The ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) constitutes the main mechanism for protein degradation within eukaryotic cells, playing a pivotal role in numerous biological functions essential for maintaining cellular homeostasis. These functions include cellular signaling, growth regulation, cell cycle control, DNA replication, and transcription [8,9]. The UPS operates as a multistage process encompassing the involvement of ubiquitin, three classes of ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes, proteasomes, and substrate proteins to mitigate the accumulation of damaged, misfolded, and aberrant proteins. Within this system, ubiquitin enzymes are subdivided into three categories: E1 (ubiquitin-activating enzyme), E2 (ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme), and E3 (ubiquitin ligase), alongside 26S proteasomes and deubiquitylating enzymes. These components collaboratively orchestrate intracellular protein ubiquitination, significantly influencing cellular viability [10,11]. Ubiquitination modifications are integral to various cellular signaling pathways, necessitating precise substrate recognition predominantly mediated by E3 ubiquitin ligases. Currently, the most commonly studied E3 ubiquitin ligases are classified into four familial groups: U-box E3s, RBR E3s, HECT E3s, and RING E3s [12,13].

The SCF (Skp1-cullin-F-box proteins) multisubunit complex is the most prevalent RING E3 ligase among these. This complex includes the scaffold protein cullin1, RING proteins RBX1 and RBX2, adaptor proteins, and substrate receptor proteins [14]. The SCF ubiquitin ligase utilizes F-box proteins to selectively recruit specific substrates for ubiquitination, which are then recognized and degraded by the proteasome [15]. Furthermore, the SCF-E3 ubiquitin ligase is instrumental in regulating various physiological processes at both cellular and organismal levels. Disruption of its functional integrity has been implicated in multiple pathologies, including neurogenic inflammation, cerebral ischemia, and various cancers [16–18]. The high substrate specificity exhibited by the SCF ligase has garnered considerable interest among researchers in the field, highlighting its potential implications in therapeutic interventions.

F-box proteins, a distinct class of proteins characterized by the presence of the F-box domain, play a pivotal role in the recruitment of specific, modified substrates to SCF (Skp1-Cullin-F-box) complexes. These proteins are integral to the ubiquitination process and subsequent degradation of target proteins across various cellular functions [19,20]. Predominantly found in eukaryotic organisms, F-box proteins exhibit a remarkable diversity in their functional roles, being implicated not only in neurodegenerative diseases, diabetes, and various cancers, including mechanisms of drug resistance, but also in critical biological processes related to fungal growth, sexual reproduction, and pathogenicity [21–23]. Extant research has highlighted the significance of F-box proteins such as MoCdc4, MoFwd1, and MoFbx15 in the growth, development, and pathogenic behavior of the plant pathogen Magnaporthe oryzae. MoFwd1 has been identified as a modulator of the circadian rhythm within this organism, affecting the transcriptional and translational regulation of the MoFRQ protein [24]. Furthermore, the filamentous fungi-specific F-box protein, Frp1, as evidenced by the frp1Δ mutant, which exhibits non-toxicity due to its failure to colonize plant roots, underscores the essential function of the FRP1 gene in mediating pathogenicity [25].

Recent investigations into C. neoformans have demonstrated that the fbp1Δ mutant of the F-box protein completely abrogates sexual reproduction and corresponding pathogenic traits [26]. Importantly, studies reveal that heat-killed fbp1Δ cells can elicit a Th1-type immune response, suggesting their potential application in vaccine development, particularly in the context of host exposure to various fungal pathogens [27]. In Candida albicans, the F-box protein CaCdc4 is critical in hindering the transition from yeast to filamentous forms and modulating cell adhesion. This protein significantly affects the organism’s virulence and biofilm formation [28]. F-box proteins can also influence replication forks within challenging genomic regions and collaborate with the intra-S phase checkpoint protein Tof1 and the helicase Rrm3, thereby significantly contributing to the maintenance of genomic stability in Saccharomyces cerevisiae [29,30]. Collectively, a comprehensive analysis of F-box proteins and identifying their downstream substrates is imperative for advancing our understanding of fungal virulence and developing effective strategies to control fungal infections.

In our earlier research, we identified the F-box protein Cdc4, which contains a potential F-box domain and eight WD40 repeats. This protein is essential for sexual reproduction and pathogenicity of C. neoformans and may also regulate cell membrane integrity and DNA damage repair [31]. In this study, we used isobaric tags for relative and absolute quantitation (iTRAQ) proteomic analysis to comprehensively evaluate the downstream substrates associated with Cdc4. Through this analysis, we identified Rnh2B as a significant downstream target of Cdc4. Functional assays demonstrated that RNH2B deletion significantly attenuated the pathogenicity of C. neoformans, while its overexpression completely abolished virulence. Host immune response analysis indicates that both the RNH2BOE strain and the cdc4Δ mutant induce comparable adaptive immune responses, promoting fungal clearance.

sec.title: Ethics approval and ARRIVE guidelines statement
sec.p: The animal studies conducted at Southwest University received approval from the Animal Ethics Committee of Southwest University (IACUC-20221022-14). The authors confirm that we have adhered to ARRIVE guidelines (Figshare: author checklist, https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.28329740.v4.

sec.title: Strains, media, and growth conditions
sec.p: The wild-type C. neoformans strains H99 and KN99a utilized in this study were obtained from the laboratory of Joseph Heitman, while the other C. neoformans strains were constructed based on these wild-type strains in our laboratory. Detailed information regarding the strains is listed in Table S1. Cultivation was conducted using yeast extract-peptone-dextrose (YPD, 2% peptone, 1% yeast extract, and 2% glucose) solid and liquid media at 30ºC. Strains harboring genes regulated by the CTR4 promoter were maintained in YPD media supplemented with 25 μM CuSO4, 1 mM ascorbic acid, and 200 μM bathocuproinedisulfonic acid (BCS), using the methodology established by Ory et al. [32]. Yeast two-hybrid experiments employed the designated yeast strain NMY32, with transformants cultured in a synthetic dropout (SD) medium deficient in leucine, tryptophan, histidine, and adenine. The macrophages referenced as J774, utilized for assessing the interaction between Cryptococcus and macrophages, were cultured in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM, 4 mM L-glutamine, 4500 mg/L glucose, 1 mM sodium pyruvate, and 1500 mg/L sodium bicarbonate) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS). This culture was maintained at 37ºC in a 5% CO2 environment, following the procedures described by Liu and Xue [33]. Preparation of other media followed the protocols previously documented by Liu et al. [26], with detailed information provided in Table S2.

sec.title: Protein extraction and iTRAQ analysis
sec.p: The H99 and cdc4Δ mutant strains were inoculated into 50 mL of YPD medium for overnight cultivation, establishing three parallel controls for each strain. Upon reaching the logarithmic growth phase, the cryptococcal cells were harvested. Protein extraction was conducted using a previously described methodology [33]. The collected cells underwent two washes with pre-cooled, sterilized deionized water before being transferred to 2 mL FastPrep® tubes. Subsequently, 600 μL of acid-washed glass beads and 1 mL of lysate buffer (comprising 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, and 1% Triton X-100) were added to the tubes. Cell disruption was achieved using the FastPrep-24 5 G apparatus (MP Biomedical, USA) under the following conditions: 6 m/s for 40 seconds, repeated eight times. Following homogenization, the supernatant was collected via centrifugation at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 20 minutes. To investigate the differential protein abundance resulting from CDC4 knockout, total protein extracts from both the H99 and cdc4Δ strains were sent to APTBIO, China, for TMT quantitative proteomic analysis [34].

sec.title: Yeast two-hybrid assays
sec.p: To elucidate the protein-protein interaction between Cdc4 and Rnh2B, we employed a yeast two-hybrid assay outlined by Osman et al. [35]. CDC4 and RNH2B Full-length cDNA sequences were amplified via PCR utilizing specific primers TL1619/TL1620 and TL1865/TL1866 (see Table S3 for primer information), respectively. These fragments were subsequently cloned into the bait vector pGBKT7, facilitating the fusion with the BD domains. Concurrently, the full-length cDNAs of CDC4 and RNH2B were re-amplified using the primers TL1841/TL1842 and TL1697/TL1698, respectively, and cloned into the prey vector pGADT7 to form fusion constructs with the AD domains. The integrity and accuracy of all cDNA sequences were verified through sequencing conducted by Sangon Biotech (Sangon, Shanghai, China). Both bait and prey vectors were co-transformed into the yeast strain NMY32. The resulting yeast transformants were cultured on selective media: SD-Trp-Leu, SD-Trp-Leu-His, and SD-Trp-Leu-His-Ade (Clontech, Dalian, China) for 2–3 days at 30°C. Transformants that exhibited growth on SD media deficient in histidine or adenine indicated a positive protein interaction. Control experiments were conducted with transformants containing pGADT7-T7 and pGBKT7–53, serving as a positive control, and those with pGADT7-T7 and pGBKT7-LAM, used as a negative control [34].

sec.title: The generation of tagged protein strains
sec.p: To develop a strain that expresses the Cdc4:3×Flag protein, we amplified the full-length cDNA of CDC4 utilizing specific primers TL1617 and TL1618. This amplified fragment was subsequently integrated into the pTBL6 plasmid (see Table S1 for plasmid information), which had been digested with BamHI, thereby generating the Cdc4:3×Flag fusion plasmid, designated pTBL285. This construction was achieved through homologous recombination employing the Hieff Clone® Universal II One Step Cloning Kit (Yeasen, Shanghai, China). The linearized pTBL285 was then biolistically transformed into the cdc4Δ strain, successfully establishing the Cdc4:3×Flag strain, henceforth referred to as TBL502.

To further investigate the interaction between Cdc4 and Rnh2B, we aimed to construct an Rnh2B-hemagglutinin (HA) fusion expression strain. Initially, we amplified the full-length RNH2B gene using primers TL1981 and TL1982. This fragment was then recombined with pTBL19, following BamHI/PstI digestion, to create the RNH2B:HA fusion expression vector pTBL414. This vector was biolistically transformed into the H99 and TBL502 strains after linearization with ScaI, as described previously [36], successfully establishing strains TBL591 and TBL574. Subsequently, total proteins were extracted and pulled down using the magnetic beads coated with either Flag or HA antibodies (Beyotime, Shanghai, China). The protein signals were then detected with Anti-Flag antibodies (Rockland) and Anti-HA antibodies (Sigma).

To evaluate the stability of the Rnh2B protein within both the H99 and cdc4Δ backgrounds, we transformed the pTBL414 into the respective strains to produce Rnh2B:HA-tagged proteins, designated as TBL591 and TBL603. These strains were grown in a liquid YPD medium with 200 μM BCS until they reached the logarithmic growth phase. The cultures were subsequently transferred to a YPD medium containing 1 mM ascorbic acid and 25 μM CuSO4 for further incubation periods of 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 hours. Protein extraction for Western blotting was performed according to previously established protocols, with the signal for Rnh2B-HA detected using an anti-HA antibody. The pre-stained standard protein used for staining in protein electrophoresis or Western blot was purchased from Accurate Biology (AG11807, Changsha, China).

sec.title: The subcellular localization of Rnh2B
sec.p: To investigate Rnh2B’s subcellular localization in C. neoformans, we amplified the coding sequence of the RNH2B gene using primers TL2230 and TL2231. This sequence was subsequently cloned into the pCN19 vector [37], which had been appropriately linearized with BamHІ/SpeІ, resulting in the creation of the GFP-RNH2B fusion expression vector, designated as pTBL457. Then, the ScaI-linearized pTBL457 vector was biolistically transformed into strain TBL547, and the resulting GFP transformants were screened and verified through epifluorescence microscopy using a fluorescence microscope (Zeiss, Axio Observer 3, Germany). Additionally, DAPI staining was employed to visualize the nuclei of C. neoformans, thereby facilitating a more precise assessment of the subcellular localization of Rnh2B, as outlined by Bahn et al. [38].

sec.title: Generation of RNH2B knockout or overexpression strains
sec.p: The rnh2BΔ mutant strains were generated in the genetic backgrounds of H99 and KN99a using a split marker strategy, as previously detailed by Kim et al. [39]. Initially, genomic DNA from H99 was employed as a template to amplify the flanking sequences upstream and downstream of the RNH2B gene, utilizing primers TL2077/TL2078 and TL2079/TL2080, respectively. Subsequently, the plasmid pJAF1 was used as a template to amplify the dominant selectable marker gene, NEO, employing TL17/TL18 as primers [40]. The upstream flanking sequence was then fused with the marker gene NEO through overlap PCR, employing primers TL2077/TL20. A similar process was undertaken to amplify the fusion fragment of the downstream flanking sequence in conjunction with the marker gene NEO, using primers TL19 and TL2080. The resulting fusion fragments were biolistically introduced into the H99 and KN99a strains after mixing. The selection of stable knockdown transformants was conducted on a YPD solid medium supplemented with G418 at a concentration of 200 mg/L. The rnh2BΔ mutant was validated through PCR with positive control primer TL2083/TL59 and negative control primer TL2081/TL2082, further corroborated by Southern blotting analysis.

To create the complemented strain of the rnh2BΔ mutant, we amplified the upstream promoter region, the open reading frame, and the downstream region of the RNH2B gene using H99 genomic DNA as the template along with primers TL2197/TL2198. The resultant PCR fragment was subsequently cloned into plasmid pTBL1, which had been linearized with BamHІ, to generate the RNH2B complementation plasmid, designated pTBL455. This plasmid was then linearized with ScaІ and transformed into the rnh2BΔ mutant strain through biolistic transformation.

For the construction of the RNH2B overexpression strain, the RNH2B gene fragment was amplified using primers TL2199/TL2200. This fragment was cloned into plasmid pTBL5, which had been linearized with BamHІ, resulting in the RNH2B overexpression vector, pTBL451. The pTBL451 was linearized using ScaI and subsequently introduced into the rnh2BΔ mutant strain through biolistic transformation. The stable transformants with overexpressed RNH2B were identified by culturing on YPD solid medium supplemented with 100 mg/L nourseothricin sulfate. Quantification of the overexpression levels was accomplished via quantitative real-time PCR analyses

sec.title: Southern blotting analysis
sec.p: Southern blotting analysis was conducted using the digoxigenin (DIG) High Prime DNA Labeling and Detection Starter Kit II (Roche, Mannheim, Germany), following the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, genomic DNA was extracted from the wild-type C. neoformans H99 strain and the rnh2BΔ mutant, then digested with XhoI. The resulting DNA fragments were separated by agarose gel electrophoresis and denatured in a solution containing 1.5 M NaCl and 0.5 M NaOH. The DNA was subsequently transferred to a nylon membrane (Roche, Mannheim, Germany) via capillary transfer. A DIG-labeled probe targeting the downstream region of RNH2B was hybridized to the membrane-bound DNA, and the hybridization signals were detected using the DIG detection system. This analysis aimed to verify genomic alterations in the mutant strain by assessing restriction fragment length polymorphism.

sec.title: Quantitative real-time PCR
sec.p: To verify the successful construction of the RNH2B overexpression strain, we assessed the mRNA levels of RNH2B through quantitative real-time PCR, utilizing H99 as a control. The overexpression strains were harvested after overnight incubation in a YPD liquid medium, followed by washing with sterile deionized water. Following the manufacturer’s instructions, total RNA was extracted and purified from C. neoformans or lung tissues using the SteadyPure RNA extraction kit (Accurate, Hunan, China). The concentration of the purified RNA was measured using a KAIAO ultramicro spectrophotometer (K5600C, KAIAO, China).

After DNA removal, cDNA was synthesized using the EvoM-MLV RT Kit with gDNA Clean for qPCR (Accurate, Hunan, China). Real-time quantitative PCR was performed using the SYBR Green Pro Taq HS premixed qPCR kit (Accurate, Hunan, China) to evaluate target gene expression, with GAPDH as a reference. The quantitative primers utilized in this investigation are detailed in Table S3. The target gene expression levels were normalized against the endogenous housekeeping gene GADPH. The relative expression of the target gene was evaluated based on the threshold cycle number (Ct) as described by Livak and Schmittgen [41]. Quantitative real-time PCR was performed using the LineGene 9600 Plus PCR system (BIOER) [34].

sec.title: Analysis of melanin, capsule production, and growth under stress conditions
sec.p: H99, cdc4Δ mutant, and Rnh2B-related strains were cultivated overnight in a YPD liquid medium at 30°C. Following cultivation, cryptococcal cells were harvested and washed twice with sterile deionized water. A 100 μL aliquot of each strain’s culture was carefully spotted onto the Niger Seed agar medium to assess melanin production. The agar plates were incubated at 30°C or 37°C for 48 hours, then photographed and evaluated for melanin synthesis.

To investigate capsule formation, overnight cultures of each C. neoformans strain were washed three times with sterile 1× PBS buffer, followed by overnight incubation at 37°C in Sabouraud medium [42,43]. The resultant capsules were stained with India ink and observed under a microscope. Capsule thickness measurements and subsequent statistical analyses were conducted using established methodologies [26].

To clarify the role of Rnh2B in the stress resistance of C. neoformans, we performed experiments examining the growth dynamics of the rnh2BΔ mutant and RNH2BOE strain on YPD agar plates with various stressors added. Cultures of each C. neoformans strain were collected overnight, washed three times with 1× PBS buffer, and then diluted to an OD600 of 2.0. Next, the yeast cells were diluted serially in ten-fold increments using ddH2O. Subsequently, 5 μL aliquots from each dilution were plated onto the agar. The plates were kept at 30°C for 2–3 days, and the growth status of each strain was recorded with photographs.

Furthermore, to evaluate how Rnh2B affects the growth of C. neoformans at various temperature conditions, we set the initial inoculum concentration to 1 × 107 cells/mL. An inoculum volume of 100 μL was incubated at 30°C and 37°C for 48 hours, with optical density (OD) measurements recorded at 2-hour intervals. The OD600 was ascertained utilizing the BMG LABTECH multifunctional microplate reader (FLUOstar Omega, Ortenberg, Germany).

sec.title: Virulence analysis
sec.p: H99, cdc4Δ mutant, and Rnh2B-related strains were cultured overnight in a YPD liquid medium. After cultivation, the cryptococcal cell suspensions underwent three washes with sterile 1× PBS buffer, adjusting the concentration to 2 × 106 cells/mL. The mice used for the virulence assay were 8-week-old C57BL/6 mice obtained from Chengdu Ensiweier Biotechnology Co., Ltd (Ensiweier, Chengdu, China). Each group of mice (n = 10) was anesthetized with 100 µL of ketamine (12.5 mg/ml)-xylazine (1 mg/ml) mixture and inoculated intranasally with 1 × 105 cells in 50 µL of 1×PBS buffer from each cryptococcal strain, as previously described [44]. Throughout the experiment, the mice were closely monitored for any signs of distress, necessitating prompt euthanasia for affected individuals, with the time of death meticulously recorded. Statistical analysis of the survival times of the mice was conducted using GraphPad Prism version 8.0, with a significance threshold set at p < 0.05.

To evaluate the virulence of each C. neoformans strain in Galleria mellonella, a series of experiments were conducted utilizing fifth-instar larvae, each weighing approximately 300 ± 50 mg and exhibiting normal motility without pigmentation. Experimental cohorts were established, with ten larvae randomly assigned to each group. The Cryptococcus strains under investigation were cultured overnight in a YPD liquid medium. After cultivation, yeast cells were collected and washed twice with sterile 1× PBS buffer. The concentration was then adjusted to 2 × 108 cells/mL. Inoculation of the larvae was performed by injecting 10 μL of the fungal suspension into the second left gastropod of each larva using a microsampler. For each experimental trial, larvae were categorized into more than three treatment groups, which included the wild-type strain H99, mutant strains cdc4Δ and rnh2BΔ, the complemented strain rnh2BΔ::RNH2B, the overexpression strain RNH2BOE, as well as a PBS control group. Post-infection, the larvae were housed in sterile petri dishes and incubated at either 30°C or 37°C [45]. The growth status of G. mellonella was monitored daily, with meticulous recording of both mortality and survival rates [46].

sec.title: Histopathology and fungal burdens in infected tissues
sec.p: Following the experiment or at designated time points, the infected mice were euthanized according to the animal protocol approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at Southwest University. Next, the mice’s lungs, brain, and spleen were carefully collected and fixed in 10% paraformaldehyde before being sent to Servicebio (Wuhan, China) to prepare tissue sections. In the survival study post-Cryptococcus inoculation, tissues from H99/rnh2BΔ-infected mice that reached a terminal moribund state were collected at the experimental endpoint (days 21–28). In contrast, tissues from cdc4Δ/RNH2BOE-infected mice, which survived until the termination of the experiment, were collected on day 80 post-infection. These tissue sections underwent H&E staining were subsequently examined microscopically to assess histopathological changes.

In parallel, the harvested tissues from the infected mice’s lungs, brain, and spleen were resuspended in 3 mL of sterile 1× PBS buffer using a homogenizer. Following resuspension, the homogenate was diluted, and a 100 μL aliquot was plated on YPD plates supplemented with ampicillin (100 mg/L) and chloramphenicol (25 mg/L). The number of colonies formed on the YPD plates was recorded after incubation for 2 to 3 days at 30°C, facilitating the assessment of fungal burdens within the tissues of the infected mice. All experimental data were analyzed statistically using the non-parametric Mann-Whitney test via GraphPad Prism version 8.0 software, with p-values less than 0.05 denoting statistical significance.

sec.title: Cryptococcus-macrophage interaction assay
sec.p: The investigation into the interactions between Cryptococcus and macrophages was conducted using 48-well cell culture plates. The J774 macrophages were cultured in a medium with 10% heat-inactivated FBS at 37°C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere. Overnight cultures of cryptococcal cells were harvested, washed, and subsequently opsonized with 20% mouse complement (S3269, Sigma). The macrophages were then quantified and adjusted to a concentration of 5 × 104 cells per well in 300 μL of fresh DMEM. Following overnight incubation, the macrophages were stimulated with 1 μg/mL lipopolysaccharide (LPS, Sigma) and 50 U/mL interferon-γ (IFN-γ, Sigma). The cryptococcal cell concentration in each well was standardized to 2 × 105 cells. After a two-hour co-incubation period, unphagocytosed cryptococcal cells were removed using DMEM, and fresh DMEM was then added. The cultures were incubated for another 0, 2, or 22 hours. Lysates were prepared by replacing the medium in each well with sterile double-distilled water to extract cryptococcal cells from the macrophages at specified time points. The lysates were subsequently spread onto YPD solid medium, and the resultant colonies on YPD plates were enumerated after 2–3 days of incubation at 30°C. Statistical analyses were conducted to evaluate the proliferation efficiency of the phagocytosed cryptococcal cells within the macrophages.

sec.title: Serum treatment assay
sec.p: To elucidate the cellular activity of C. neoformans in serum environments, we conducted a serum incubation analysis using Rnh2B-related strains. Cultures of each cryptococcal strain were harvested overnight and washed with sterile double-distilled water, resulting in a final concentration of 1 × 106 cells/mL. A total of 50 μL of the resuspended cryptococcal cells was combined with 450 μL of serum. Samples were subsequently incubated at 37°C for varying durations of 1, 2, 3, and 4 hours. Following incubation, samples were subject to dilution and plated onto a YPD medium supplemented with 100 mg/L ampicillin and 25 mg/L chloramphenicol. Colony counts were meticulously recorded after 2–3 days of incubation at 30°C, facilitating an assessment of Cryptococcus cell viability.

sec.title: Collection of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid
sec.p: After euthanasia with 100 µL of a ketamine (12.5 mg/ml)-xylazine (1 mg/ml) mixture, the mouse trachea was exposed by carefully excising the neck muscles with scissors. A small incision was made in the trachea without severing it completely. A 21T plastic sleeve was affixed to the needle of a 5 mL syringe, which was then carefully inserted into the incision in the trachea, and the needle and trachea were secured with a fine thread. Subsequently, 1 mL of pre-cooled 1×PBS buffer supplemented with 5 mM EDTA was slowly injected, and then the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) was withdrawn and collected. This procedure was repeated three times. Centrifuge at 4°C, 400×g, for 10 min, collect the supernatant, and store at −80°C for future use.

sec.title: Detection of cytokines via ELISA
sec.p: After thawing alveolar lavage fluid and serum samples, the liquids were centrifuged at 2500 rpm for 10 minutes at 4°C to separate cell debris from the supernatant. Before initiating the assay, the experimental kits were equilibrated at 25ºC for 30 minutes. Subsequently, 50 μL of various concentrations of standard solutions were added to each designated standard well. For sample wells, 10 μL of the samples and 40 μL of sample dilutions were incorporated per the manufacturer’s protocol. Except for the blank wells, each well received an HRP-conjugated detection antibody, which was incubated at 37°C for one hour. Post incubation, the liquid was carefully discarded, and each well was rinsed five times with a washing solution to remove unbound antibodies. Following the wash steps, 50 μL of Substrate A and Substrate B were added to each well, and the mixture was then incubated at 37°C in the dark for 15 minutes. After this incubation period, 50 μL of termination solution was added, and the OD was measured at 450 nm within a 15-minute window. The ELISA kits utilized for detecting mouse IFN-γ, IL-4, IL-13, IL-17A, and IRF4 were procured from Youxuan Biotechnology (Youxuan, Shanghai, China).

sec.title: Preparation of single-cell suspensions from mouse lung tissue
sec.p: Single-cell suspensions from murine lung tissue were generated following the methodology outlined by Rivera et al. [47]. Lung tissue was harvested and mechanically dissociated using scissors. Following this, 1 mL of pre-cooled 1× PBS buffer was introduced to the tissue, and a wash was performed. The processed tissue was subsequently transferred to a 10 mL centrifuge tube, where 5 mL of 1× PBS buffer containing 3 mg/mL collagenase IV (Coolaber, Beijing, China) and 30 μg/mL DNase I was added. The enzymatic digestion proceeded for 1 hour at 37°C, with gentle inversions every 10 minutes to ensure thorough interaction between the enzyme and substrate. The digestion was concluded with three washes utilizing 1× PBS buffer. Red cell lysis buffer (TIANGEN, Beijing, China) was employed to eliminate residual erythrocytes from the suspension. The supernatant was carefully removed via centrifugation and then washed with 1× PBS buffer at 2500 rpm for 5 minutes. Ultimately, the resulting cell clusters were resuspended in an appropriate volume of cell staining buffer (Elabscience, Wuhan, China), with the dilution set at 100 μL of cell staining buffer per 106 cells.

sec.title: Analysis of flow cytometry
sec.p: Single-cell suspensions derived from murine lung tissue were subjected to staining procedures to identify various immune cell populations. Monocytes and neutrophils were labeled using the following antibodies: CD45 (Elab Fluor Violet 450 [30-F11]), CD11b (PerCP/Cyanine5.5 [M1/70]), Ly6C (PE [Monts 1]), and Ly6G (APC [1A8]). For the identification of CD4 and CD8 T cells, the antibodies utilized were CD45 (Elab Fluor Violet 450 [30-F11]), CD3 (PE [17A2]), CD4 (PerCP/Cyanine5.5 [RM4–5]), and CD8 (APC [53–6.7]). Dendritic cells were characterized using CD45 (Elab Fluor Violet 450 [30-F11]), CD11b (PerCP/Cyanine5.5 [M1/70]), CD11c (FITC [N418]), MHCII (PE [M5/114]), and CD40 (APC [FGK4.5/FGK45]).

Following the resuspension of the single-cell suspensions in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS, the cell suspension was transferred to 24-well cell culture plates and incubated at 37°C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere. Each 500 μL aliquot of the cell suspension was stimulated with 2 μL of PMA/Ionomycin for 2 hours, after which an additional stimulation with 2 μL of BFA/Monensin was performed for 4 hours. Upon completion of the stimulation, the cells were harvested and resuspended in a cell staining buffer. The surface staining for CD4+ T cells was conducted utilizing a combination of CD3 (PE [17A2]), CD4 (PerCP/Cyanine5.5 [RM4–5]), and CD8 (APC [53–6.7]) antibodies. Following surface staining, cells were washed with cell staining buffer, and 100 μL of fixation buffer was added before fixation at room temperature for 30 minutes. Subsequently, 1 mL of permeabilization buffer was introduced, followed by gentle mixing. After centrifugation at 400 ×g for 5 minutes, the cells were washed twice. The cells were then resuspended in 100 μL of permeabilization buffer and co-incubated in the dark with fluorochrome-conjugated antibodies against IL-17A (Elab Fluor Violet 450 [17F3]), IFN-γ (FITC [XMG1.2]), and Foxp3 (PE [3G3]) for 30 minutes. Following incubation, 1 mL of cell staining buffer was added, and the mixture was gently mixed. The cells were then centrifuged at 400 ×g for 5 minutes and washed twice. Following the final wash, 100 μL of cell staining buffer was added to resuspend the cells. All flow cytometry antibodies employed in this analysis were sourced from Elab Science. The immune cell populations were subsequently analyzed using a Beckman CYTOFLEX flow cytometer (Beckman, IL, USA) in conjunction with CytoExpert software.

sec.title: Identification of Rnh2B
sec.p:
Cdc4 plays an essential role within the E3 ubiquitin ligase complex of C. neoformans, functioning as an F-box protein that selectively identifies downstream substrates for proteolytic degradation. To clarify the target proteins affected by Cdc4, we conducted an iTRAQ-based proteomic analysis to compare protein expression profiles of the H99 strain with those of the cdc4Δ mutant. In this comparative analysis, we identified a total of 5234 proteins that are shared between the H99 and the cdc4Δ mutant strains (Figure 1(A)). Proteins were classified as differentially expressed based on a quantitative ratio exceeding a threshold of 1.2-fold (i.e. fold change > 1.2 or < 0.83) and a significance level indicated by a P-value of < 0.05. Utilizing these criteria, we identified 150 upregulated and 28 downregulated proteins in the cdc4Δ mutants (Figure 1(B,C)). Table 1 lists a selection of proteins exhibiting increased abundance in the cdc4Δ background. The substrates downstream of Cdc4 are regulated by the UPS, leading to their accumulation in cdc4Δ mutants. Consequently, our investigation primarily concentrated on the proteins that accumulated. Figure 1.
Identification of proteins in H99 and cdc4Δ mutant backgrounds using the iTRAQ analysis. (A) 58123 peptides and 5,234 proteins were identified in H99 and cdc4Δ mutant backgrounds. (B) Up and downregulated proteins in the cdc4Δ mutant background compared with the wild-type H99 strain. 141 proteins exhibited upregulated abundance, while 25 displayed downregulated abundance. FC, Fold change. (C) Up and downregulated proteins in the cdc4Δ mutant background are presented in a volcano map.Table 1.
Partial high abundance proteins identified in the cdc4Δ mutants of C. neoformans..
AccessionDescriptionAveragecdc4Δ/H99No. of PEST Domain
CNAG_00826Dihydroxyacetone kinase1.3841252
CNAG_00827Ribose 5-phosphate isomerase1.5630051
CNAG_01796Uncharacterized protein1.6353320
CNAG_02132Uncharacterized protein1.6961401
CNAG_04027Protein CASP1.3522270
CNAG_04219Lactoylglutathione lyase1.6404680
CNAG_04220ATP-dependent DNA helicase II subunit 11.4383393
CNAG_04257Uncharacterized protein1.5041761
CNAG_042304-methyl-5-beta-hydroxyethylthiazole kinase1.4203512
CNAG_04752Uncharacterized protein1.3765850
CNAG_04261Ribonuclease H2 subunit B Rnh2B1.4528701
CNAG_04314NAD kinase1.3850381
CNAG_05258Glucose-methanol-choline oxidoreductase1.9082862
CNAG_05316Inositol oxygenase2.1226611

Among the accumulated proteins identified, a particularly noteworthy candidate, designated CNAG_04261, is significantly enriched in the cdc4Δ mutant and possesses a Ribonuclease H2 Ydr279 domain. To elucidate the functional role of CNAG_04261 as a downstream substrate of Cdc4, we conducted a comprehensive analysis of its gene structure. We utilized Fungi DB and other relevant genomic databases to determine that the CNAG_04261 gene spans 1553 base pairs and is characterized by seven introns and eight exons (Figure 2(A)). The corresponding protein sequence comprises 328 amino acids, predominantly featuring the ribonuclease H2-Ydr279 domain (Figure 2(B)). Notably, the amino acid sequence exhibits approximately 51% identity and 68% similarity with the Ribonuclease H2 subunit B of Papiliotrema laurentii (Figure 2(C)), indicating a potential functional similarity between these two proteins. Consequently, we have designated CNAG_04261 as Rnh2B in C. neoformans. Figure 2.
Identification of the Rnh2B in C. neoformans. (A) The sequence structure of the Ribonuclease H2 subunit B gene RNH2B in C. neoformans. (B) The Rnh2B contains an RNase H2-Ydr279 functional domain in C. neoformans. (C) Sequence alignment of C. neoformans Rnh2B (Cn) and Papiliotrema laurentii Rnh2B (Pl). The two proteins have 51% identity and 68% similarity. (D) Rnh2B is localized in the nuclei of cryptococcal cells. The yeast cells expressing GFP-Rnh2B were observed using a fluorescent microscope (Zeiss, Axio Observer 3, Germany). The nuclei of yeast cells from the GFP-Rnh2B strain were stained with DAPI solution. Scale bar, 5 μm. (E) Localization of GFP-Rnh2B in yeast cells under different stress conditions. CR: Congo red; SBT: Sorbitol; MMS: methyl methanesulfonate; Scale bar: 5 μm.

sec.title: Rnh2B is situated within the nucleus of Cryptococcus cells
sec.p: To determine Rnh2B localization in C. neoformans, we engineered the GFP-RNH2B plasmid and introduced it into the rnh2BΔ mutant to create a GFP-Rnh2B fluorescent strain. The localization of Rnh2B within the yeast cells was examined using a fluorescence microscope (Zeiss, Axio Observer 3, Germany) in C. neoformans. Our observations revealed that Rnh2B is predominantly localized in the nucleus of C. neoformans (Figure 2(D)).

Considering that C. neoformans faces various stress conditions during the infection process, we next sought to determine whether these stress conditions affect the localization of Rnh2B within C. neoformans. We conducted an examination of the Rnh2B localization in C. neoformans under diverse stress conditions, including cell wall stresses (0.5% Congo red or 0.025% SDS), osmotic stresses (1.5 M NaCl, 1.5 M KCl, or 1.5 M Sorbitol), high-temperature stress (37°C), DNA alkylation damage repair stress (0.04% MMS), and nutritional deficiency (SD-N). Our findings indicated that these stress conditions did not alter Rnh2B localization in C. neoformans (Figure 2(E)).

sec.title: Rnh2B interacts with Cdc4
sec.p:
Our proteomics analysis revealed that Rnh2B protein levels are elevated in the cdc4Δ mutant, suggesting it may be a substrate for ubiquitination mediated by Cdc4 (Table 1). In a cdc4Δ mutant background, a Cdc4 substrate is expected to accumulate due to insufficient ubiquitination and degradation. The potential interaction between Rnh2B and Cdc4 was investigated through yeast two-hybrid assays. We cotransformed the yeast strain NMY32 with constructs of Rnh2B and Cdc4, fused to the activation domain (AD) or binding domain (BD). Transformants with interactions were identified on an SD medium devoid of histidine (SD-Leu-Trp-His) or adenine (SD-Leu-Trp-His-Ade). This study supported that Rnh2B interacts with Cdc4 (Figure 3(A)). Figure 3.
Rnh2B interacts with Cdc4 and is a substrate of Cdc4. (A) Rnh2B interacts with Cdc4 in a yeast two-hybrid interaction assay. The full length of the cDnas of RNH2B and CDC4 were fused with either the activation domain of vector pGADT7 or the binding domain of vector pGBKT7. These fusion constructs were transformed into the yeast host strain NMY32, and colonies cultivated on selective SD medium lacking leucine and tryptophan were analyzed on media that also lacked histidine and both histidine and adenine. Yeast cells harboring AD-T7 and BD-LAM or empty vectors pGADT7 and pGBKT7 were utilized as negative controls, while those expressing AD-T7 and BD-53 fusion proteins served as positive controls. (B, C) Rnh2B interacts with Cdc4. Proteins from cryptococcal cells expressing Cdc4–3×Flag, Rnh2B-HA, or both Cdc4–3×Flag and Cdc4-HA were extracted and purified. The potential Cdc4-Rnh2B interaction was investigated via Co-IP using anti-Flag (B) or anti-HA antibodies (C) and assessed by immunoblotting. (D) The stability of the Rnh2B protein is dependent on the expression of Cdc4. The PCTR4-RNH2B:HA construct was expressed in the wild-type (H99) or cdc4Δ mutant background. Cells were cultured in YPD until they reached the mid-logarithmic phase. Following the addition of CuSO4 to halt RNH2B transcription at the indicated times, Rnh2B levels were examined through immunoblotting with an anti-HA antibody. The expression of the tubulin gene served as a loading control. (E) The data illustrate the ratio of the band intensity of each Rnh2B protein to the corresponding tubulin at the indicated times. (F) Proteins from cryptococcal cells of the wild type (W) and the wild type (H) or the cdc4Δ mutant (Δ) expressing Rnh2B-HA were extracted and purified with an anti-HA antibody. The ubiquitination of Rnh2B-HA was evaluated by immunoblotting with an anti-ubiquitin antibody. The expression of Rnh2B-HA under the wild-type or cdc4Δ mutant backgrounds was verified through immunoblotting with an anti-HA antibody. The expression of the tubulin gene was used as a loading control.

To explore the interaction between Rnh2B and Cdc4 more thoroughly, we constructed an Rnh2B:HA fusion expression vector using the pCTR4–2 vector, featuring a copper-repressible promoter, CTR4. The Rnh2B:HA fusion construct was subsequently incorporated into a strain that expresses Cdc4:3×Flag (TBL502). Total proteins were purified from the strains expressing Cdc4:3×Flag and Rnh2B:HA using SureBeads™ anti-HA and anti-Flag magnetic beads (Bio-RAD), followed by immunoblotting with either anti-HA or anti-Flag antibodies. The simultaneous detection of Flag and HA signals in the co-immunoprecipitation product confirmed the interaction between Rnh2B and Cdc4 in C. neoformans (Figure 3(B,C)).

sec.title: Rnh2B stability depends on Cdc4 function
sec.p: Cdc4, a crucial element of E3 ubiquitin ligases, performs a significant function in regulating the ubiquitination levels of diverse downstream substrates. To investigate Cdc4’s potential regulatory effect on the ubiquitination of Rnh2B, we assessed the stability of the Rnh2B protein as well as its ubiquitination in C. neoformans. Initially, we constructed an Rnh2B-HA plasmid containing the CTR4 copper ion inhibitor-type promoter and introduced it into both H99 and cdc4Δ mutant strains. We then evaluated the stability of Rnh2B-HA protein in H99 and cdc4Δ mutant backgrounds. Both strains were grown overnight in a YPD broth supplemented with 200 μM of bathoproproinediulonic acid to inhibit the CTR4 promoter via copper ions. After washing with 1× PBS buffer, the cultures were moved to a YPD broth supplemented with 1 mM ascorbic acid and 25 μM CuSO4. Yeast cells were harvested at 0, 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 hours in culture, and Rnh2B-HA expression levels were measured by Western blotting analysis. The findings show that Rnh2B-HA expression diminished over time in the wild-type H99 strain but stayed consistent in the cdc4Δ mutant background. This finding indicates that the stability of Rnh2B-HA relies on Cdc4 (Figure 3(D,E)).

Subsequently, total proteins were extracted and purified from the H99 and cdc4Δ mutant strains using magnetic beads conjugated with HA antibodies. The polyubiquitination of Rnh2B-HA was then detected via immunoblotting employing anti-HA and anti-ubiquitin antibodies. As illustrated in Figure 3(F), the ubiquitination level of Rnh2B protein was significantly reduced in the cdc4Δ mutant background compared to the H99 background strain. This finding suggests that Cdc4 plays a role in regulating the ubiquitination process of the Rnh2B protein. In conclusion, Cdc4 is implicated in regulating Rnh2B ubiquitination, indicating that Rnh2B functions as a downstream substrate of Cdc4.

sec.title: Rnh2B ensures cell membrane integrity and growth under osmotic stress
sec.p:
To evaluate the function of Rnh2B in Cryptococcus, we developed RNH2B knockout mutant strains rnh2BΔ (TBL547 and TBL566, verified through PCR and Southern blot; data not included) in the H99 and KN99a backgrounds, along with RNH2B complemented strains rnh2BΔ::RNH2B (TBL595) and RNH2B overexpression strains (RNH2BOE, TBL585, and TBL586). The RNH2B gene’s overexpression was validated using Western blotting (Figure 4(A)) and qRT-PCR (Figure 4(B)). Figure 4.
Rnh2B is required for cell membrane integrity and growth under osmotic stresses. (A) The Rnh2B-HA expression of RNH2BOE strains was detected using Western blotting with an anti-HA antibody. α1, α mating type RNH2B overexpression strain #1; α2, α mating type RNH2B overexpression strain #2; a, α mating type RNH2B overexpression strain. (B) Detection of the RNH2B expression of RNH2BOE strains using qRT-PCR. α1, α mating type RNH2B overexpression strain #1; α2, α mating type RNH2B overexpression strain #2; a, α mating type RNH2B overexpression strain. (C) Growth of the Cryptococcus strains under different stress conditions for two days at 30°C. MMS, methyl methanesulfonate. Strain’s name is shown on the left, and the condition is indicated on the top. C. neoformans cell growth was assayed in a BMG LABTECH multifunctional enzyme labeling instrument (FLUOstar Omega, Germany). Briefly, 100 μL of inoculum (1 × 107 cells/mL) was incubated at 30°C (D) or 37°C (E) with shaking (200 rpm), and the OD600 was measured in real time every 2 hours. Each experiment was performed in triplicate.

We investigated how Rnh2B influences the virulence of C. neoformans by examining three key virulence factors: melanin production, capsule formation, and growth at 37°C in both the rnh2BΔ mutant and the RNH2BOE strain. Our research indicates that the capsule size in the rnh2BΔ mutant and the RNH2BOE strain does not exhibit a statistically significant difference compared to that of the wild-type strain H99 (Figure S1(A,B)). However, melanin production was markedly diminished in the RNH2BOE strain relative to H99 (Figure S1(C,D)), and this strain exhibited significantly impaired growth at 37°C (Figure 4(C)). We also explored how Rnh2B-related strains grow under different stress conditions. Compared with the H99, both the rnh2BΔ strain and the RNH2BOE strain demonstrated increased sensitivity to YPD +1.5 M KCl and YPD +1.5 M NaCl (Figure 4(C)), suggesting that the homeostatic expression of RNH2B is essential for maintaining the osmotic pressure of Cryptococcus cells. Meanwhile, we observed that the RNH2BOE strain displayed heightened sensitivity to YPD + 0.04% methyl methanesulfonate (MMS) (Figure 4(C)), indicating that RNH2B overexpression may compromise the repair of DNA alkylation damage. This observation aligns with previous findings that Rnh2B can disrupt genome stability in S. cerevisiae [48].

At the same time, we comprehensively evaluated the growth traits of both the rnh2BΔ mutant and the RNH2BOE strain in a liquid YPD medium. Our data show that at 30°C, the growth rates of the rnh2BΔ mutant and the RNH2BOE strain were similar to those of the other strains examined (Figure 4(D)). However, when incubated at 37 ºC, a substantial decline in growth rate was observed for these strains compared to the H99 strain (Figure 4(E)). The findings indicate that the RNH2B gene is critical for cellular growth under high temperatures and conditions of high osmotic pressure, thereby implicating Rnh2B in the pathogenetic mechanisms of C. neoformans.

sec.title: Rnh2B controls C. neoformans virulence
sec.p:
Rnh2B maintains cell membrane integrity and supports growth under osmotic stress, indicating its potential role in the virulence mechanisms of C. neoformans. A mouse inhalation model was employed, wherein female C57BL/6 mice were infected intranasally with 105 yeast cells per individual. The findings are illustrated in Figure 5(A). Mice that were infected with the wild-type H99 strain showed a mortality peak approximately 20 days post-infection (dpi), and all subjects died by 26 dpi. In contrast, the rnh2BΔ mutant strain exhibited mortality beginning at 60 dpi, with four mice surviving until 80 dpi, indicating that the absence of Rnh2B significantly attenuates the pathogenicity of C. neoformans. Notably, the RNH2BOE strain remained viable and asymptomatic throughout the experimental period, concluding at 80 dpi (Figure 5A). Figure 5.
Rnh2B regulates the virulence of C. neoformans. (A) the survival rate of the mice after the infection in a mouse systemic infection model. Female C57BL/6 mice were infected with 10 5 yeast cells of the wild-type H99, cdc4Δmutant, rnh2BΔ mutant, and the RNH2BOE strain. ****, p < 0.0001 (determined sathya ||query brains, and spleens of five mice infected with H99, cdc4Δmutant, rnh2BΔ mutant, and the RNH2BOE strain were isolated at the end time point of the infection (day 21–28 for H99/rnh2BΔ-infected mice reaching moribund status; day 80 for cdc4Δ/RNH2BOE-infected mice surviving to experimental termination). Homogenates of the organs were prepared for CFU counting. The data shown are the mean ± SD for the values of five mice. Died: mice infected with rnh2BΔ mutant died before 80 dpi; Survived: mice infected with rnh2BΔ mutant survived at 80 dpi when we ended the experiment. ***, p ≤0.001; ****, p ≤0.0001 (determined by Mann-Whitney test). (C) H&E-stained slides from the cross-sections of infected organs were prepared at the endpoint of the infection and imaged by microscopy. The yeast cells are indicated by arrows. Bars: 20 μm. (D) The survival rate of G. mellonella infected by H99, cdc4Δmutant, rnh2BΔ mutant, rnh2BΔ::NEO complemented, and the RNH2BOE strain at 30°C and 37°C. A log-rank test was utilized to analyze the differences in pathogenicity of the Wax moth larvae infected with each Cryptococcus strain. ***, p < 0.001, ****, p < 0.0001.

Our previous findings established that the cdc4Δ mutant exhibited a complete loss of pathogenicity following infection in mice (Figure 5(A)), a result that correlates with the total loss of pathogenicity observed in the RNH2BOE strain. This suggests that Cdc4 May modulate the pathogenic potential of C. neoformans through its downstream substrate, Rnh2B. After the infection, the mouse lungs, brains, and spleens were divided in half, fixed, and sent to Wuhan Servicebio Technology Co., Ltd. for H&E tissue section staining. The remaining tissues were homogenized and cultured on a YPD medium to assess the fungal burden in the tissues. As depicted in Figure 5(B), the colony-forming units (CFUs) found in the lungs of rnh2BΔ-infected mice were significantly lower than those infected with the H99 strain, irrespective of the mice’s survival outcomes. Following the experiment, no yeast cells were found in mouse tissues infected with the RNH2BOE strain.

Furthermore, the formation of fungal lesions in mouse tissues was analyzed using light microscopy on H&E-stained sections. Observations revealed that both H99 and the rnh2BΔ mutant strains caused varying degrees of tissue damage in the brains, lungs, and spleens, characterized by a significant presence of yeast cells within the tissues, which likely exacerbates immune cell recruitment and contributes to immunopathology-associated damage in the brains, lungs, and spleens (Figure 5(C)). Conversely, no yeast cells were detected in the tissue slices from the RNH2BOE group, and no tissue damage was indicated (Figure 5(C)). These findings further substantiate the complete loss of pathogenicity associated with the RNH2BOE strain.

In Figure 4(C,E) we observed a significant impairment in the growth of the RNH2BOE strain at 37°C. To further investigate whether the reduction in pathogenicity of the RNH2BOE strain was attributable to temperature sensitivity, we conducted infection experiments using C. neoformans on Galleria mellonella larvae at both 30°C and 37°C. The experimental results, depicted in Figure 5(D), demonstrated that at 30°C, the pathogenicity of the RNH2BOE strain and the cdc4Δ mutant strain was markedly diminished compared to the group infected by H99. Notably, at 37°C, all larvae infected with the H99 strain died by 6 dpi, whereas the survival duration of larvae infected with the RNH2BOE strain and the cdc4Δ mutant strain extended beyond 15 days. Quantitative analysis revealed comparable survival curves between RNH2BOE and cdc4Δ mutant infections at both temperatures (Figure 5(D)).

To elucidate the mechanisms underlying the virulence attenuation of the RNH2BOE strain, a comprehensive time-course investigation was conducted to ascertain the fungal burden within host tissues and evaluate the progression of the disease. Mice were exposed to inhalation infections using H99, cdc4Δ, and RNH2BOE strains, with subsequent isolation of brain, lung, and spleen tissues collected at 1, 3, 5, and 7 dpi (Figure 6(A)). The dynamics of C. neoformans within the host were meticulously analyzed during the initial phases of infection. Figure 6.
Progression of RNH2BOE strain infection in organs of infected mice. Lungs, brains, and spleens of the mice infected by the wild-type H99, cdc4Δ mutant, and RNH2BOE were isolated at 1, 3, 5, and 7 dpi. (A) A detailed diagram that illustrates the various time points at which samples were collected following infection with Cryptococcus in mice, designed to reflect a synchronized time-course study. The number of CFUs was measured in lung (B), brain (C), and spleen (D) homogenates. The data shown are the mean ± SD for the values of five mice. ns, not significant. ***, p < 0.001; ****, p < 0.0001 (determined by Mann-Whitney test). (E) H&E slides were also prepared from the cross-sections of the lungs, brains, and spleens and observed by light microscopy. Arrows indicate the yeast cells. Bars: 20 μm.

The findings indicated that, as time elapsed, there was a marked increase in CFUs within the lung tissue of the H99-infected mice, as illustrated in Figure 6(B). Cryptococcus cells were detectable within mouse brains and spleens infected with the H99 strain at 7 dpi, as described in Figure 6(C,D). In stark contrast, the RNH2BOE strain exhibited a gradual decline in the number of yeast cells within the lung tissues of the inoculated group, with no viable cells recoverable at 5 dpi. At four specific time points, no cryptococcal cells were detected in the brains and spleens of mice infected with the RNH2BOE strain (Figure 6(C,D)). As in our earlier findings, the cdc4Δ mutant strain employed as a control did not produce any recovered yeast cells from the brains and spleens of infected mice at the four specified time points (Figure 6(C,D)); however, yeast cells could be isolated from the lungs of infected mice, showing a gradual and slow decrease in CFU (Figure 6(B)). Light microscopy with H&E staining was used to examine the development of fungal lesions in mouse organs infected with C. neoformans. As depicted in Figure 6(E), at 1, 3, 5, and 7 dpi, cryptococcal cells were readily observable in the pulmonary tissue of mice infected with both the H99 and the cdc4Δ mutant strains. In contrast, pulmonary tissues from RNH2BOE-infected mice showed minimal to no detectable cryptococcal cells. No fungal lesions were observed in brain or spleen tissues for any strain during the study period. Quantitative analysis confirmed the absence of disseminated infection in RNH2BOE-infected mice across all examined organs.

sec.title: Rnh2B is crucial for the survival of fungi within macrophages and the host’s complement system
sec.p:
To clarify the involvement of Rnh2B in modulating the pathogenicity of C. neoformans, we evaluated the growth dynamics of the H99, rnh2BΔ mutant, cdc4Δ mutant, and RNH2BOE strain in the context of the host complement system and macrophage interactions. We first performed serum treatment assays using murine serum to simulate the proliferative conditions that arise post-invasion of C. neoformans within the host. The data revealed that both the RNH2BOE strain and the cdc4Δ mutant demonstrated markedly reduced survival and proliferation in the host environment than the wild-type H99 strain, suggesting a substantial impact of the complement components present in host serum on the survival of both the RNH2BOE strain and the cdc4Δ mutant (Figure 7(A)). Figure 7.
Rnh2B plays an important role in fungal survival within the host’s complement system and macrophages. (A) The proliferation of C. neoformans after co-incubation with fetal bovine serum (FBS). Overnight cultures of the H99, rnh2BΔ mutant, cdc4Δ mutant, and RNH2BOE strain were mixed with FBS and incubated at 37°C for the indicated times. One hundred microliters of the dilute (103 dilution) was spread on YPD plates, and the CFU counts were used to measure the Cryptococcus cell viability. ***, p < 0.001 (determined by Mann-Whitney test). (B) The proliferation of Cryptococcus inside the macrophage was performed using the J774 murine macrophage cells. After incubation for the indicated time, the lysates from the macrophage cultures were spread on YPD plates, and the CFU counts were used to measure the intracellular proliferation and macrophage killing. ***, p < 0.001, as analyzed by the Mann-Whitney test. (C) The proliferation of C. neoformans in DMEM medium. For comparison, the growth of the strains in (B) was also measured in DMEM without macrophages.

Furthermore, our findings in the Cryptcoccus-macrophage assay demonstrated that phagocytic efficiency was comparable across the H99, rnh2BΔ mutant, cdc4Δ mutant, and RNH2BOE strain at both the 2-hour and 4-hour time points. However, following a 24-hour coincubation period, both the rnh2BΔ mutant and cdc4Δ mutant, and the RNH2BOE strain exhibited a statistically significant decline in viability relative to the H99 strain (Figure 7(B)). In a complementary analysis, we evaluated the fungal growth rate in DMEM devoid of macrophages and found that the H99, rnh2BΔ mutant, cdc4Δ mutant, and RNH2BOE strain demonstrated comparable growth rates in this medium (Figure 7(C)).

Collectively, these findings show that the RNH2BOE strain has reduced survival and growth in murine serum. After phagocytosis by macrophages, this strain’s proliferation is significantly lower compared to the H99 strain.

sec.title: Overexpression of RNH2B induces stronger immune responses in mouse lungs
sec.p: The innate immune response is a vital initial defense against fungal pathogens in fungal pathogenesis. Key innate immune cells, such as macrophages, dendritic cells, and recruited neutrophils, participate in phagocytic activity and cytokine secretion to combat these invaders. Simultaneously, adaptive immune cells, particularly Th1 and Th17 cells, contribute to the antifungal response by producing specific cytokines, notably Interferon-γ and IL-17A [49].

Chemokines are pivotal in directing immune cell migration to sites of inflammation, thereby facilitating the synthesis and secretion of cytokines and promoting the phagocytosis of pathogens [50]. Notably, CXCL1 is implicated in neutrophil recruitment, while CCL2/CCR2 serves a similar function for monocytes [51–53]. Furthermore, chemokines such as CXCL10/CXCR3, CCL17, and CCL20 are involved in the differentiation and migration of Th1 cells and the recruitment of Th2 and Th17 cells to inflamed tissues, respectively [54–56].

To clarify how the RNH2BOE strain reduces its virulence, we examined the expression of chemokines in lung tissues during the initial stages of infection. Our findings indicated that at 1 dpi, the RNH2BOE strain was associated with increased recruitment of neutrophils coupled with a decreased recruitment of Th2 immune cells to the lungs (Figure 8(A)). Furthermore, at 3 dpi, there was a marked increase in the recruitment of neutrophils, monocytes, and Th1 immune cells to the lungs in response to the RNH2BOE strain (Figure 8(A)). Notably, Th17 immune cells were recruited following five days of infection with the RNH2BOE strain. Figure 8.
Cellular responses in mice following Cryptococcus infection. (A)The alterations in chemokine expression within the lungs during the early stages of infection. The mRNA levels of chemokines CXCL1, CCL2, CXCL10, CCL17, and CCL20 were quantified using qRT-PCR, with GAPDH as the internal control. Statistical significance was evaluated using a two-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparisons test in GraphPad Prism 8.0. *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001; ****, p < 0.0001. (B-C) the changes of cytokines in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (B) and serum (C) during the early infection stage. The concentrations of IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, IL-17A, and IFN-γ were measured. Statistical significance was evaluated using a two-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparisons test in GraphPad Prism 8.0. *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001; ****, p < 0.0001. (D) inflammatory responses of mice infected with the cdc4Δ mutant and the RNH2BOE strain. The extent of cellular infiltration in the lungs was evaluated by flow cytometry. Data representation is provided as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). Statistical analysis was done with the Kruskal-Wallis non-parametric test for multiple comparisons with GraphPad Prism 8.0. *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001; ****, p < 0.0001.

In comparison, the group infected with H99 demonstrated a significant increase in neutrophil recruitment within lung tissue on day one post-infection with the cdc4Δ mutant. Additionally, three days post-infection with the cdc4Δ mutant, there was a pronounced augmentation in the recruitment of neutrophils, monocytes, Th1 cells, and Th17 cells to the lung tissue (Figure 8(A)). Overall, overexpression of RNH2B elicited a more robust immune response in the lungs following infection in murine models, thereby enhancing the recognition and clearance of pathogens by pulmonary immune cells.

Th1 cells are pivotal in orchestrating a protective immune response against infections caused by C. neoformans. However, this pathogen has evolved mechanisms to subvert host immune defenses, particularly through promoting Th2 cell-mediated immunity. Additionally, Th17 cells significantly combat pathogenic fungi by enhancing neutrophil recruitment and the secretion of antimicrobial peptides [57]. In our follow-up analyses, we evaluated cytokine levels produced by different T cell subsets: IFN-γ from Th1 cells, as well as IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 from Th2 cells, and IL-17A from Th17 cells. These cytokines are instrumental in establishing an inflammatory milieu and act on various immune cells to facilitate their recruitment and activation, as well as the secretion of antimicrobial peptides and the induction of fungicidal activity. The findings revealed that RNH2BOE infection significantly reduced IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 levels at 1 dpi (Figure 8(B)). At 3 dpi, we noted increased levels of IFN-γ and IL-17A, alongside a sustained decrease in IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 in the BALF of mice infected with RNH2BOE (Figure 8(B)). Additionally, RNH2BOE infection was linked to elevated levels of IFN-γ and IL-17A. In contrast, mice infected with the H99 strain demonstrated higher secretion of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 by day five of infection (Figure 8(B)). In the cdc4Δ-infected cohort, a significant increase in IL-17A levels was detected at 1 dpi (Figure 8(B)). By day three, elevated levels of IL-17A and reduced levels of IL-5 and IL-13 were documented (Figure 8(B)). Five days after infection with the cdc4Δ strain, we observed increased levels of IFN-γ and IL-17A, while levels of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 decreased.

The results show that mice infected with either the RNH2BOE strain or the cdc4Δ mutant primarily exhibited Th1 and Th17 pulmonary immune responses. Together, these responses contributed to a more robust protective immune response against the fungal pathogens. In contrast, mice infected by the H99 strain exhibited a predominant Th2-mediated immune response, suggesting a different protective mechanism. Subsequently, in our investigation, we assessed the cytokine expression patterns in the serum of infected mice, with the results illustrated in Figure 8(C). At 1 dpi, RNH2BOE infection was associated with elevated levels of IFN-γ and concomitant reductions in IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. The group infected with RNH2BOE showed markedly elevated levels of IFN-γ compared to the H99-infected group. Conversely, IL-4 and IL-13 levels were notably reduced in the RNH2BOE-infected group at 3 dpi compared to the H99-infected group. Additionally, at 5 dpi, RNH2BOE infection was linked to elevated levels of IFN-γ and IL-17A, while serum concentrations of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 were reduced in mice.

In comparison to the H99-infected group, mice infected with the cdc4Δ mutant showed significantly reduced serum levels of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. Analysis of cytokine expression in BALF indicates that RNH2BOE infection enhances immune responses of Th1 and Th17 in both pulmonary and systemic environments, while simultaneously inhibiting Th2-type immune responses. This alteration in the immune milieu appears to enhance the host’s ability to combat invading fungal pathogens.

sec.title: Overexpression of RNH2B triggers adaptive immune response in mouse lungs
sec.p: To enhance the understanding of the specific immune cell types involved in the immune response within the pulmonary tissues of hosts following RNH2BOE and cdc4Δ mutant infections in a murine model, we executed a comprehensive flow cytometry analysis on lung samples harvested from infected mice. This analysis focused on the recruitment of neutrophils, monocytes, dendritic cells, CD4+ and CD8+ T cells within the pulmonary environment of infected mice.

We comprehensively investigated lung tissue following infection with the H99, cdc4Δ mutant, and RNH2BOE strains at 1, 3, and 5 dpi. A meticulous preparation of a single-cell suspension from lung tissue was performed, and the corresponding immune cell populations were identified using specific antibodies designed for flow cytometry analysis. Notably, the lung tissue of mice infected with the RNH2BOE strain exhibited significant recruitment of monocytes at 3 dpi, along with increased levels of monocytes, neutrophils, and dendritic cells by 5 dpi (Figure 8(D), panels 1–3). These results indicate that the RNH2BOE strain infection elicits a more robust innate immune response than the H99 strain. Additionally, we observed a significant increase in monocytes and dendritic cells within the lung tissue, just 1 dpi with the cdc4Δ mutant infection (Figure 8(D), panel 1). At 3 dpi following infection with the cdc4Δ mutant, there was an observable further elevation in the levels of monocytes. Furthermore, at 5 dpi, there was a marked increase in neutrophil levels (Figure 8(D), panel 2).

To investigate the adaptive immune response elicited during C. neoformans infection, we comprehensively analyzed the recruitment dynamics of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells (Figure 8(D), panels 4–5). Our findings reveal that mice infected with RNH2BOE exhibited a significantly enhanced recruitment of CD4+ T cells within the pulmonary microenvironment. While the levels of CD8+ T cells in this cohort were generally elevated compared to the H99-infected group, the observed differences did not reach statistical significance. Notably, CD4+ T cell levels increased on the third day following cdc4Δ infection when juxtaposed with the H99-infected cohort. Additionally, by 5 dpi, both CD4+ and CD8+ T cell levels significantly increased. These results suggest that a strengthened CD4+ T cell response predominantly characterizes the adaptive immune response induced by RNH2BOE and the cdc4Δ mutant, highlighting the essential function of CD4+ T cells in immune defense against C. neoformans infection.

Recent investigations have emphasized the critical role of the immune response mediated by IFN-γ-producing Th1-type and IL-17-producing Th17-type CD4+ T cell lymphocytes in controlling cryptococcosis. Both Th1 and Th17 immune responses are instrumental in facilitating antifungal defenses through the activation of classical macrophages, which are pivotal for eradicating C. neoformans and mitigating extrapulmonary fungal infections [58]. Notably, C. neoformans undermines protective immune mechanisms and exacerbates disease progression by promoting Th2 cell activation, producing key cytokines such as IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 [59]. Given the significance of CD4+ T cell subsets in the immune response against C. neoformans infections, we further assessed the IL-17- and IFN-γ-producing CD4+ T cell levels within the lung tissues of an infected murine model, employing both surface staining and intracellular staining techniques in flow cytometry. Our data indicate that at 1, 3, and 5 dpi, there is a notable increase in the proportion of CD4+IFN-γ+ Th1 cells (marked by PC5.5-A+FITC+) and CD4+IL-17A+ Th17 cells (marked by PC5.5-A+PB450+) in the lung tissues of mice infected with the cdc4Δ strain when compared to those with H99 infection. Representative fluorescence-activated cell sorter (FACS) plots of CD4+IFN-γ+ Th1 and CD4+IL-17A+ Th17 cells in BALF are shown in Figure 9. Significantly, at 1 and 5 dpi, the counts of CD4+IFN-γ+ Th1 cells in the lung tissues of mice infected with the RNH2BOE strain were substantially elevated compared to the H99 control group (Figure 10(A)). Likewise, at 1, 3, and 5 dpi, the levels of CD4+IL-17A+ Th17 cells in the lung tissues of mice infected with the RNH2BOE strain were considerably higher than those in the control group (Figure 10(B)). Figure 9.
The analysis of adaptive CD4+ T cells in the lungs of infected mice. (A) The flow cytometry of CD4-IFN-γ T cells; (B) The flow cytometry of CD4-IL-17A T cells. Representative fluorescence-activated cell sorter (FACS) plots of CD4+ (left) and CD8+ (right) T cells in BALF. Figure 10.
The analysis of adaptive CD4+ T cells in the lungs of infected mice. (A) the ratio of CD4+ IFN-γ+T cells. (B) the ratio of CD4+ IL-17A+T cells. Significance was evaluated using a two-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparisons test in GraphPad Prism 8.0. *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001; ****, p < 0.0001.

The percentage of CD4+ IFN-γ+ T cells within the lung tissue of mice infected with the RNH2BOE strain was significantly elevated compared to the H99-infected cohort on both the first and fifth days post-infection (Figure 10(A)). Additionally, the proportion of CD4+ IL-17A+ T cells in the lung tissue of mice infected with RNH2BOE was significantly higher compared to those in the H99-infected group on the first, third, and fifth days post-infection (Figure 10(B)). In the cdc4Δ mutant-infected group, notable elevations in the proportions of both CD4+ IFN-γ+ T cells (Figure 10(A)) and CD4+ IL-17A+ T cells (Figure 10(B)) were also observed compared to the H99-infected cohort. These findings suggest that the RNH2BOE strain induces stronger innate and adaptive immune reactions within host lung tissue following infection, potentially inhibiting the colonization of C. neoformans in the lungs and its subsequent dissemination to other organ systems.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The ubiquitin-proteasome system constitutes a vital intracellular pathway pivotal for protein degradation and plays a fundamental role in regulating various cellular processes, including transcriptional control, cell cycle progression, endocytic recycling, sexual reproduction, mitochondrial connectivity, circadian rhythm maintenance, and pathogenicity [60–63]. As essential constituents of the SCF-E3 ubiquitin ligase complex within this system, F-box proteins specifically recognize downstream substrates, thereby facilitating their ubiquitination and subsequent degradation. Previous investigations have elucidated the regulatory functions of F-box proteins concerning the pathogenicity of the human fungal pathogen C. neoformans. Notably, knockout mutants of the FBP1 and CDC4 genes exhibit a complete loss of pathogenicity in murine infection models [26,31]. However, the precise molecular mechanisms by which F-box proteins recognize and regulate the pathogenicity of C. neoformans through their substrates remain inadequately understood.

In this study, we have identified Ribonuclease H2 subunit B (Rnh2B) as a downstream substrate of the F-box protein Cdc4 through iTRAQ-based LC-MS proteomics analysis. Our yeast two-hybrid results provide preliminary support for the interaction between Cdc4 and Rnh2B (Figure 3(A)). Subsequent co-immunoprecipitation (Co-IP) assays (Figure 3(B–D)) offer essential biochemical validation of this interaction. Our findings demonstrate that Rnh2B directly interacts with Cdc4, and the ubiquitination and degradation of Rnh2B are contingent upon the presence of Cdc4. Moreover, subcellular localization studies indicate that Rnh2B is predominantly localized in the nucleus of C. neoformans, and this nuclear localization remains largely unaffected by external stressors. Virulence assessments of C. neoformans demonstrate that the rnh2BΔ mutant exhibits significantly diminished pathogenicity, whereas the RNH2BOE overexpression strain exhibits a complete loss of virulence. Furthermore, analysis of the host immune response reveals that both the RNH2BOE strain and the cdc4Δ mutant elicit a heightened immune response in the host, effectively clearing the pathogen. This robust immune response is likely a principal factor contributing to the observed loss of pathogenicity in these two strains. In conclusion, our findings suggest that the F-box protein Cdc4 regulates the virulence of C. neoformans by modulating its downstream substrate, Rnh2B.

RNA and DNA can form transient RNA-DNA structures during replication and transcription, which significantly influence genomic stability [64,65]. In S. cerevisiae and Mus musculus model organisms, RNase H2 plays a critical role in removing ribonucleotides from genomic DNA and is essential for proper embryonic development in mice [66,67]. Yeast strains deficient in RNase H2 demonstrate an increased ribonucleotide content, rendering them susceptible to low concentrations of methyl methanesulfonate (0.015% MMS) and hydroxyurea (25 mM HU) [68]. Notably, single mutations in the two non-catalytic subunits of RNase H2, RNH202 and RNH203, do not confer sensitivity to replication stress induced by 25 mM HU; in contrast, double mutants exhibit heightened sensitivity under similar conditions [68,69]. Furthermore, mutations in the human genes encoding ribonucleases have been associated with Aicardi-Goutières syndrome, a debilitating autosomal recessive neurological disorder [70]. Despite these findings, the role of RNase H2 in the pathogenicity of human fungal pathogens, such as C. neoformans, Aspergillus fumigatus, and Candida albicans, remains underexplored in current research.

Based on our preliminary findings, we first examined the role of Rnh2B in the development and formation of virulence factors in C. neoformans. In comparative analyses with the wild-type H99 strain, the RNH2BOE strain exhibited a pronounced reduction in growth at 37ºC. Prior research conducted by our group indicated that the cdc4Δ mutant did not exhibit significant growth differences at 37ºC compared to the wild-type H99 strain [31]. Given that Rnh2B is a downstream substrate of the Cdc4 protein, it was anticipated that the RNH2BOE strain would display a phenotype analogous to that of the cdc4Δ mutant. Contrarily, the observations revealed that the RNH2BOE strain exhibited a reduced growth rate at 37ºC, possibly due to the overexpression of the RNH2B gene. Therefore, further research is necessary to clarify how RNH2B overexpression affects the growth of C. neoformans at 37ºC.

Subsequently, we investigated the pathogenicity of both the rnh2BΔ mutant and the RNH2BOE strain in greater detail. The results indicated that the RNH2BOE strain exhibited a complete loss of pathogenicity when compared with the wild-type H99 strain (Figure 5A), which aligns closely with our earlier observations, wherein the cdc4Δ mutant strain also demonstrated a total loss of pathogenicity [31]. This correlation suggests that Cdc4 May play a crucial role in modulating the pathogenicity of C. neoformans by regulating Rnh2B. The comparison between the wild-type strain H99 and the RNH2BOE strain reveals intriguing insights into the mechanisms underlying virulence. The significant growth impairment observed in the RNH2BOE strain at 37°C suggests that temperature may play a crucial role in its pathogenicity. This raises important questions about how temperature sensitivity could be linked to the overall virulence of fungal strains. To delve deeper into this issue, we conducted infection experiments using C. neoformans on G. mellonella larvae at both 30°C and 37°C. The findings, illustrated in Figure 5(D), highlight a marked reduction in pathogenicity for both the RNH2BOE strain and the cdc4Δ mutant strain at 30°C compared to the H99 strain. This suggests that lower temperatures may contribute to diminished virulence; however, the temperature dependency does not fully explain the observed differences.
