Interestingly, at 37°C, the results were striking. All larvae infected with the H99 strain succumbed by 6 dpi, while those infected with the RNH2BOE strain and the cdc4Δ mutant survived well beyond 15 days (Figure 5(D)). This significant discrepancy indicates that the RNH2BOE strain’s reduced virulence stems from intrinsic defects rather than mere thermal sensitivity. Overall, the G. mellonella infection model confirmed that this attenuated virulence was due to intrinsic defects in the RNH2BOE strain rather than thermal sensitivity.

Macrophages function as the first line of defense against C. neoformans invasion into the host’s airway and are pivotal determinants of the host’s infection outcome [71,72]. Consequently, we investigated the mechanisms underlying the complete loss of pathogenicity observed in the RNH2BOE strain. Experiments involving mouse serum incubation and the interactions between C. neoformans and macrophages revealed that both the cdc4Δ strain and the RNH2BOE strain exhibited analogous phenotypes, characterized by significantly diminished survival rates in the host complement system and reduced proliferation capabilities within macrophages relative to the wild-type H99 strain (Figure 7). These findings may elucidate the observed loss of pathogenicity in the RNH2BOE strain in the mouse inhalation infection model.

The protective immunity against C. neoformans depends on the intricate recognition, regulation, and interaction of innate and cell-mediated immune responses [73]. In this context, we conducted a thorough investigation of the innate and adaptive immune responses in the pulmonary tissues of murine models infected with the Cryptococcus H99, cdc4Δ mutant, and RNH2BOE strains at 1, 3, and 5 dpi (Figure 8(A)). Notably, during the early stages of infection, elevated levels of Th1 cytokines, specifically IFN-γ, and Th17 cytokines, including IL-17A, were detected in the BALF from mice infected with the cdc4Δ and RNH2BOE strains (Figure 8(B)). In contrast, BALF from mice infected with the H99 strain exhibited significantly higher concentrations of Th2 cytokines, namely IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 (Figure 8(C)). We meticulously analyzed the composition of immune cells within the lung tissues using flow cytometry. Our findings revealed that mice infected with cdc4Δ and RNH2BOE demonstrated significantly elevated levels of monocytes, neutrophils, and dendritic cells at early time points post-infection (Figure 8(D)), suggesting that these strains elicited a more vigorous innate immune response compared to the H99 strain.

Furthermore, we assessed the recruitment dynamics of CD4+ and CD8+ T cell populations in the infected pulmonary tissues. The adaptive immune responses in mice infected with cdc4Δ and RNH2BOE were predominantly mediated by CD4+ T cells in the early infection phase (Figure 8D), corroborating previous studies that indicate the emergence of adaptive immunity, mainly via CD4+ T cell responses, as a critical factor when fungal pathogens penetrate pulmonary physical barriers and innate immune mechanisms [74,75]. Our investigation further elucidated an increase in IFN-γ+ Th1 and IL-17A+ Th17 cell populations in the lungs of mice infected with the cdc4Δ mutant and RNH2BOE strains (Figure 9). Additionally, a trend toward elevated levels of CD8+ T cells was observed in the lungs of mice infected with RNH2BOE relative to H99; however, this difference did not achieve statistical significance (Figure 8(D)). In contrast, the population of CD8+ T cells in the lungs of cdc4Δ mutant-infected mice was significantly higher than that observed in H99-infected mice by 3 dpi (Figure 8(D)). This observation indicates that during C. neoformans infection, CD8+ T cells may compensate for the depletion of CD4+ T cells, thereby underscoring the critical involvement of both CD4+ and CD8+ T cell-mediated immune responses in the host’s capacity to clear C. neoformans effectively [76,77].

The phenomenon of immune protection conferred by strains of C. neoformans following host infection has garnered considerable attention in recent studies. Notably, Zhai et al. and Pham et al. illustrated that the overexpression of the zinc finger protein Znf2 facilitates the differentiation of host pulmonary CD4+ T cells into protective Th1 and Th17 T helper cell subsets within 7 dpi [78,79]. This strain has demonstrated potential as a vaccine, providing sustained protection against C. neoformans infections. Previously, our research group identified the F-box protein Fbp1, with its gene knockout mutant, fbp1Δ, displaying an avirulent phenotype in murine infection models [26,33]. Mechanistic analyses revealed that the low virulence associated with the fbp1Δ mutant is correlated with robust host immune responses. The fbp1Δ mutant markedly influences the immunogenic potential of C. neoformans [80] and has been employed to elicit host protection against various invasive fungal diseases in murine vaccine models [27,77]. The current study demonstrates that the RNH2BOE strain prompts the differentiation of CD4+ T cells into Th1 and Th17 subsets within the host lung (Figure 9), thereby establishing a foundation for further development of the RNH2BOE strain as a potential vaccine to confer immunogenic protection during C. neoformans infection.

Through this study, we have established the Ribonuclease H2 subunit B Rnh2B as a novel downstream substrate of the SCF E3 ligase component Cdc4 in C. neoformans. Our findings reveal, for the first time, that Cdc4-mediated regulation of Rnh2B represents a previously uncharacterized virulence modulation mechanism in this pathogenic fungus. Proteomic analysis demonstrated that Cdc4 directly interacts with and likely ubiquitinates Rnh2B, with functional consequences observed through phenotypic characterization of RNH2B deletion and overexpression strains. Notably, the RNH2BOE strain exhibited a complete loss of pathogenicity, yet paradoxically induced robust CD4+ T cell-mediated adaptive immunity. These observations have prompted further investigation into the potential application of attenuated RNH2BOE strains as live vaccine candidates against C. neoformans H99 infection. The identified Cdc4-Rnh2B regulatory axis presents promising immunotherapeutic targets that warrant deeper exploration in subsequent studies.
